step.context: %text If $\tan^{-1}x=\theta$, what is $\tan 2\theta$ in terms of $x$? %

step.reason: \begin{align} \tan 3\theta &= \tan (\theta +2\theta) \\ &=\dfrac{\tan\theta + \tan 2\theta}{1-\tan\theta \tan 2\theta} \\ &=\dfrac{x+\frac{2x}{1-x^2}}{1-\frac{2x^2}{1-x^2}} \\ &=\dfrac{x(1-x^2)+2x}{1-x^2-2x^2} \\ &=\dfrac{x-x^3+2x}{1-x^2}=\dfrac{3x-x^3}{1-x^2} \\ \therefore 3\theta &= \tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{3x-x^3}{1-x^2}\right) \end{align} \\ %text Since $\theta+2\theta=3\theta$, the given equation is proved. %
